review_title: Great Culture But Personalities in Your Reporting Structure are Important
pros: Company places high value on having a dynamic, hard-working work force. 1) Listens and acts on employee feedback; excellent benefits above usual, eg winter and summer shutdown weeks and many extra holidays, in addition to generous paid time off. 2) Currently has excellent financial position and good prospects for mid and long term appreciation of (stock) value. Depending on your level, this can translate into excellent renumeration. 3) Fun and central Boston location in Seaport (also in San Diego and Oxford, UK; Paddington UK). Most departments have at least some hybrid on-site/remote flexibility. 4) Many "irons in the fire" for new therapeutic areas, any of which could provide fantastic career opportunities and company growth. 5) C-suite unsurpassed. All members have magic combination of knowledge/experience, drive, acumen, and emotional intelligence. All will talk with any employee in the hall. 6) If you are driven and hard working, and can roll with occasional personality friction, you should definitely go work at Vertex.
cons: 1) Like many places there are small fiefdoms. If the sub-culture in these suit you then gold, if not it can range from exasperating to driving you and the best colleagues out the door. I have seen this in more than one department over the years. As an example, I once had a line manager who would freak out if I would talk about anything material to any management level above them. This is a big red flag. Recommend that you talk to as many people as possible during interview and offer stages to get sense of the sub-culture, which is just as or more important than the great macro-culture. Ask about their colleagues, boss, boss's bosses. Ignore this at your peril. Maybe won't break the deal for you, but at least you will have better idea what your getting into. 2) A sense of urgency is good, but some mid to upper level managers seem to foster and thrive on crisis-of-the-day adrenaline rush. 3) While you do have flexibility in schedule and career path, you are expected to work hard and creatively. Exceeding expectations is the expectation. Some managers are better than others in supporting you in this. The micro managers are typically detrimental, which leads to career stagnation. Even so, Vertex is above average in helping you find a way out of this, e.g. by opening up alternative career paths. 4) This is a company that is constantly growing and transforming. I don't see this as a true con, but sometimes "May you live in interesting times" can be considered a challenge (curse?!).

pros:

If you're deciding whether to work for a big company or a social justice organization you don't have to decide as this company is both. They seem to absolutely embrace social justice beyond anything I would have ever expected. I don't think it's for show. I think they are the real deal. If you're passionate about social justice issues they are also. 

The pharmaceutical part is changing lives. If you care about a company that is actually making the world a better place this is also a good pick. There were massive cons for me but I wouldn't say everyone will experience them.

I had incredible work life balance. There's so much time off I didn't know what to do with it. I've never worked at an organization that took off time like this. When they said closed for the end of the year they were absolutely closed and that was shocking to me.
cons:
The macro company is great but you don't work in the macro you have to deal with your small silo. That's a big con.

Very siloed work environment. How siloed? Well I dropped off my computer to the office and received a box to mail it back about 6 days later. No one seems to communicate. Teams I had to deal with are actively hostile towards each other. I felt absolutely zero collaboration. To me this is a very toxic environment. 

There is either no ability or no desire to plan at all. You wake up and you're not sure of what the day holds. That makes things really hard to work around.

Senior "leadership", let's just call it management, are incredibly opaque with any actions. I never felt like I had any idea what they were planning on doing or why. I didn't feel like there was any leading just micromanaging.

Here's the big con I wish I thought more about. Why is such a large part of the compensation pushed into the future? Will you be there long enough to get all that money? Don't spend your sign-on bonus for the first year because if you leave you owe it back (all of it , not pro rated, including the taxes you never saw) immediately and they take wires, bank and cashier's checks. No, that's not a typo. I found this out with two days left in my two week notice which my boss claimed was a surprise. I don't have reason to doubt him as he was great but it was a surprise.

My bosses boss admitted there was no career mobility for me so that was certainly a factor in leaving.

If you are, as used in the movie Jerry Maguire, a 'paycheck player' then you are liable not to be happy here.

pros: The people at Vertex are some of the most motivated, knowledgeable and cooperative team players I have worked with in the past 22 years. Although I worked in Clinical Development Execution, these great people were from legal, clinical pharmacology and medical affairs as well. I worked with Vertex as a contractor for 10 years because of the people. The company is proactive and ethical, actively concerned about the patients they serve and involved in the local community. As a contractor the salary was competitive.
cons: Since the company is now public, the corporate culture has changed resulting upper management determining unrealistic timelines for study execution without input from the study execution team. Upper management has been unresponsive to feedback and requests for adequate support staff to meet increasingly tight timelines.  Employees and contractors routinely work weekends and evenings resulting in poor work/life balance.

pros: Very supportive company in the community.  Brilliant support of the patients who are the #1 in our eyes.  I heard there's chance for growth, outside of my department.  Pretty good benefits package!
cons:
Can I be honest?  My department didn't promote based on achievement and hard work.  It was a popularity contest.  I've watched people come and go, regardless of their stellar performance and potential.  I've seen people with drive and proven delivery sit in the same position for more than a year while others come and get promoted for being in the "in" club.  It's very discouraging and HR or UPPER UPPER management needs to do something about that.  You're going to lose a lot of incredible talent, or are losing...  
You can tell the new employees reviews (< 6 months) vs. the seasoned (> 6 months) based on the happiness factor.   There is poor visibility, and no promotions based on merit.  Buyer beware....

pros: The projects were challenging and the management was great....
cons: There was not a clear growth path

pros:
Good Benefits
Sense of purpose at work
Innovative research technology
cons: Fast pace of projects and timelines

pros: Good salary and benefits. Probably the reason why people join.
cons: Work life balance is abysmal, the expectation is that you all even till midnight if that is what it takes. Senior management have a blame culture and favouritism is rampant.

pros: Great Pipeline, innovation, good benefits and salaries, intelligent people, incredibly respected from scientific community, lots of opportunities for growth and development, encourages open communication but, not sure they "hear it", clean reputation, tons of excitement about the future
cons: New commercial team spends money like water. Too many "directors", everyone around here has a director title but, nowhere is their job description so it is hard to know who to go to for what. Top heavy and too many field managers, already seems like same old big brother big pharma company. Way too much HR time and money spent checking up on their field team and has already created and environment of fear (quotas, reach & freq)which is the death sentence for motivation and success of a sales team. You hired the right people with tons of experience, why the hyper management? Forget seeing your wife and kids until next year, if you're single that'll be 2 years!

pros: Benefits, pay , weekly beer hour , new building . Some good people if you have good intuition on who you can trust.
cons: working at Vertex was THE biggest mistake . The only pro I can think of is that it led me to a much better job . HR is a complete and utter joke . Management entertains and promotes the lazy brown nosers and the actual hard workers are reprimanded for not being like them . This causes the trouble makers to be in charge making incredible salaries and that what makes up 80% of Vertex. Literally it's a bunch of wanna be cool , ignorant , very unintelligent and insecure people  running the departments .

review_title: NOT the best place to work
pros: Benefits, although Boston area biotech  is competitive and others will likely match
cons:
Smart people don’t stay long, and those that do stay are unhappy. 
Very disorganized.
Management dictates everything, changing their minds all the time and expecting everyone to comply, no questions asked.
Pipeline too diverse; management shooting in all directions; unfocused

review_title: An incredible company with an inspiring culture
pros: I can honestly say this is one of the most incredible companies to work for.  The energy is palpable.   The people are collaborative and motivated to bring medicines and hope to patients.  The culture is heavily science-oriented, but everyone feels like part of the mission, even those who are not necessarily scientists or physicians.  Very strong leadership team.  Amazing performance as a company.  Opportunities abound to make an impact, and grow.
cons: Still maturing as a company from a small biotech to the global biopharma leader we are today....some processes need to be optimized.  This requires everyone, at every level, to be "in the weeds" from time to time, but not overly burdensome.

pros: Vertex has a beautiful building in a great location. They have an impressive (although quite expensive) cafeteria and offer competitive wages. Their mission to promote STEM to area high school students through their Learning Lab is commendable.
cons: The company culture here is absolutely terrible. It is a constant high stress, sky is falling environment, where a minor mistake on the smallest, lowest priority task is treated like a war crime. It is an email heavy environment so you must be on it at all times or face accusations that you are "ignoring" certain people if you don't reply to an email within 10 minutes. You end up working very long hours, including nights and weekends, just responding to the barrage of emails that come in at any time. The amount of micromanagement is exhausting and you only get ahead in this company if you say yes to everything. There is also a lot of negative publicity about the lavish salaries of the executive team and the cost of our medication.

pros: The Boston location is in the heart of the seaport and the building is beautiful.
cons: Unfortunately this company has taking a turn for the worst.  GMDA was once a group that worked collaboratively for the greater good. Now, it is a completely toxic culture, which is lead by fear.  It is now the norm to see the senior management throw their team under the bus, back-up and do it again. There is no leadership at the VP level, no desire to listen or help employees (HR is a joke), and horrible discrimination based on gender/race/ethnicity. Be certain that if you try to talk to HR or a senior leadership there will be significant retaliation. Do not be fooled! The pay and benefits are not that good, you will never get anything above a 3% pay raise and promotions are extremely difficult. There is zero work-life balance, as senior management expects you to work round the clock to hit the ridiculous timelines they set in order to be able to brag about being the fastest drug company to bring new products to market.

pros: Though I have not been at the company for long, I have come to appreciate how talented and dedicated my colleagues are; a quality that I have come across all the departments that I have had the opportunity to work with. Though the work is very demanding, upper management tries to do their best to recognize everyone's efforts by providing flexible hours, optimizing work-life balance, and providing opportunities for cross-departmental interactions where colleague can learn more about how their contributions fits in the larger scheme of the company's goals and the various patient communities.  I am truly humbled to be part of the Vertex team!
cons: I do not have any negative comments to enter in this space. I do have one recommendation to upper management, which I will enter in the next section.

review_title: Decision making by consensus and changing for change's sake - if you like that kinda thing, you'd love it there!
pros: Location, benefits are phenomenal, vacation time = 4 weeks at start, not including the week between Christmas and New Year's for shutdown, people I worked alongside were great. Very flexible work environment - often booked huddle rooms to get work done if my workspace was too crazy, or I could work from home when needed.
cons: Managers there are hit or miss;  not everyone is open to coaching staff when it's necessary. I had several mgrs in a short time period, only one of them was effective. Another one gossiped about direct reports to each other and also peers. Never felt like anything discussed in our 1/1s was going to stay between us for long.  Also never felt like I could truly take time off without checking in multiple times a day.

pros: The people really understand what your strengths are.    They ask for your feedback in terms of what could be done better.  The people rally to help you out in your projects.  You're assigned some worthy projects that you're able to dive into.  You're provided with tools necessary to do your job.  They invest in you, they think thoughtfully through how they can support, and they encourage you.  The bonus awards are there to recognize you in all of your efforts.  The environment is thoughtfully decorated and makes your day as pleasant as possible.  Cafeteria is passable -- at least they have one.
cons: Sometimes, despite your trying to prove yourself, your position is not heard as thoughtfully as you might hope for.  You try hard, you put a lot of effort in, and sometimes, you're just met with silence, lack of approval, or ignored.  Morale could be a lot better.  The downside of working in a pharmaceutical environment is that drug candidates take years and years and years to get to the market.  And throughtout that process, the FDA can easily pull the plug on a candidate.  You invest a lot of time and effort -- and with one bad clinical trial, all that work disappears.

review_title: Time to Clean out the Middle Managers
pros: Amazing benefits, vacation time and one off perks! Great coworkers and an opportunity to have an impact on life threatening diseases. Lots of learning and resume building opportunity that you don't necessarily  get at other companies (how many other companies in the area have successfully brought drugs to the market in the past 5 years, let alone multiple drugs?).
cons: Current culture is very different even from a few years ago. Middle managers (department heads especially) have adopted a "do as I say, not as I do" attitude. Bad behavior is rampant in many forms - screaming and yelling at meetings, temper tantrums in the office and gossiping with direct reports. There also seems to be a lack of opportunity for promotion for those in the lower / entry level positions.

review_title: The grass IS greener at Vertex
pros:
The benefits are amazing: bonuses with stock awards, competitive pay, 5 weeks vacation to start (4 weeks + company shutdown between 12/24 and 01/01), training opportunities, weekly beer hour, extra holiday due to the Orkambi launch, telecommuting opportunities, the list goes on. Since I started, any time I have a question or need clarity on a problem, everyone I've encountered has been approachable and helped me figure things out. It's the first place I've worked where you can actually START working on your first day.

Oh wow, I totally forgot the best part - the LOCATION!
cons: Cons here are typical of any workplace: quirky people, the lifers who are somewhat hesitant to change. I think most people who've known only Vertex think that there are companies out there who treat their employees better, but as someone who's worked in several of the bigger companies in the area, I can honestly say that employees are treated VERY well at Vertex. The benefits aren't anything to complain about.

review_title: Great comp & bens, hell after a few months
job_title: Administrative Associate IV in Paddington, England
pros:
Great onboarding for new employees
Salary and benefits (which is the only reason people start/stay)
Great office location 
Usually some type of BS campaign being held every week, free food.
cons:
Senior management appear to lack basic communication skills.  (My team were called in for a "team update" when a co-worker had been fired, it was extremely uncomfortable)
Bullying is rife and goes unchecked, across more than just my dept and across all levels.
Admins are expected to do way above the norm by working many long hours!  
**NB although if you have the right Manager you can also get away with doing the bare minimum, enabling you to take as many smoke breaks outside when you want, 2hr lunches plus extra long coffee breaks, can also farm out your duties to other admins (got to be in the know though)
If you aren't up to the job, you're shown the door very quickly (no coaching or support given)
Promotions are generally only given to "favourites" no matter how hard you work, or length of service.
During my service I saw countless numbers of people leave, both pushed and jumped, but nothing is ever addressed, so you either like it or lump it!

pros: Great company culture and company wide start up training on job. Great benefits packages.
cons: Management will use administrative staff as personal secretary. Will make you believe your position will go somewhere and that you're making good money, but it's not worth the degrading work you have to do to get there (at least with the head of clinical trials management). Duties were far from what was anticipated after interview. Duties will include bringing blanket to manager when cold in meetings, cleaning up meeting messes, answering to children of manager's non-work-related phone calls, and being overall degraded by manager. From what I have heard, other departments are great to work with, however, if you don't want to be humiliated as a human, DO NOT work for this department.

review_title: Unstable, rocky executive team, but great benefits
pros: Amazing benefits- pay next to nothing for health insurance and you get great coverage, great stock plan, good 401k matching, 6 weeks of PTO. Great people in research, beautiful location.
cons: Unstable company, layoffs are happening left and right. Promotions and recognition awards are based on favoritism, stress level is very high, people do not feel there is any job stability there, they began outsourcing a lot of administrative programs last year and those have taken a nose dive in reliability and thoroughness (relocation, benefits, etc). I think the CEO is shaping the company for sale so no one should feel stable there for the next few years.

review_title: Shiny buildings but for how long?
pros: Benefits and work life balance are outstanding here. Facilities, cafeteria, gym, are great.  Decent camaraderie among employees.  Good internal employee resource networks. Some people do want to improve things but they seem to be few and far between.
cons: I don't feel in my day to day patients are mentioned much. Despite this not being a huge company (`2000 people), some chains of communication and processes feel extremely hierarchical.  I get the sense that many are here just to collect a pay check and do the bare minimum to get by- certainly not as much passion as I have seen in other pharma/biotech companies in this area.  Pipeline questionable- don't know for how much longer we will have these big shiny buildings. High turnover in the Clin Ops section. People don't seem to question anything, they just do it.

pros:
Great salary and benefits:
-10%+ yearly bonuses with 20-50% stock awards that vest over 3 years.
-4 weeks vacation to start and company shut down between Christmas and New year
-$300/month commuter benefit, charitable donation matching, and $125/month student loan payment 
-401k is just OK with 100% match for up to 3% and 50% match for an additional 1-3%

I am lucky that I work on a team with a manager who is supportive, empathetic, and reasonable. The people I work closest with are smart, helpful, and generally easy to work with. Like most places, your experience will vary depending on the department and immediate team.

Vertex as a whole is extremely successful, and I take pride in working for a company that focuses on rare genetic diseases and research.
cons:
All the comments about senior management in GMDA are spot-on. The comment about adding barriers instead of value is particularly accurate.

Extra layers of process and review add inefficiencies and confusion. Decision makers are either unresponsive, unreasonable, or can't agree with each other. They also want their hands in every. little. thing. 

Vertex talks a big talk about wanting to support its employees, help them grow, maintain work-life balance, "push decision making down and out" (please), but never follows through. There is a lot of unnecessary pressure and finger-pointing that leads to fear and burnout. They badger and bribe employees to complete an "optional" development plan so that they can say they got 100% participation and claim they did something to support employee development; whether the content of these plans is actually useful is another story.

Vertex also talks big about innovation and excellence,  but, in my department in particular,  opportunities are decided by seniority instead of merit. I am told time and again that I'm ahead of my peers who have been here longer, and yet they get most of the choice projects and growth opportunities. People are ridiculously sensitive about fairness.

review_title: Vertex has become a company without a soul
pros: Really smart people work there.
cons: In 2 words: senior management.  The goals are set by senior management and they set unattainable goals and then hold everyone to achieving them.  Senior management is out of touch with the workforce.  They do not care about people or patients.  They are driven by their personal bonuses and corporate profit.  There is no loyalty to employees.  Everyone is viewed as a replaceable commodity.  They like to talk about work place diversity but the executive team is exclusively white, middle aged men.  The environment is highly adversarial.  Those that want to climb the corporate ladder step on one another to get recognition from senior management.

pros:
- great benefits - but they have changed the compensation package many times
- on-site caf is fabulous
cons:
- don't care about employees. bottom line. HR is only for legal protection. 
- turnover high due to constant reorgs. new mgt. 
- bully mgt style and "do as I say but not as I do" 
- not nibble - big pharma players
- no work life balance

pros: Vertex provides excellent benefits- good health, dental and life insurance, great vacation time policy, stock options provide considerable value.  Financially stable.  Commitment to patients.  Track record of innovative science.
cons: Favoritism is rampant.  Unfortunately some senior leaders take advantage of their positions and push the wrong people up the ladder. Promotions are often NOT merit based- people promoted with no leadership skills or records of success.

review_title: Toxic BD Group - don't work for or with!
pros: Strong senior management below the Executive Team that gets things done.
cons: BD organization has been a revolving door for the past decade or more.  Not a partner of choice with other companies and poor alliance management.  Acting head of BD likes to slander team and members of management.  Fits in with culture of senior leadership disappearing in the middle of the night without a trace - most of time it is based upon personality clashes.  CFO now has too much say in science and questionable morals.

review_title: A Good Company To Work For (Until It's Not)
pros: The company itself does very well, and I liked the company's approach to pharmaceuticals, investigating areas that needed attention, not just the ones that were going to make the most money.
cons: In my area of work, senior management micro-managed my team.  Further, I did not like how I was laid off.  Noone likes to be laid off, of course, but there was no notice, it was not performance-based, I was simply pulled into an office and told that they were going in a different direction and I was no longer needed.

pros: Excellent science and one of the best R&D scientists I’ve ever worked with.   The Pharm Sci department seems really top notch. Pay is average in the industry and the benefits are good
cons:
Vertex has always been a hard place to work.  Before joining 9 years ago I was ” warned” about the culture.  It is not for the faint of heart.  Don’t get fooled but the “ Best Place to Work” propaganda.  This place works you to death.  While there I know 7 people who separated from their spouses due to  Never being around, mostly due to the unrealistic brutal drug development timelines they insist on everyone delivering on.   Every drug, even drugs they have very little understanding if the biology or chemistry has to get into humans faster and faster... unrealistic demands.  Remember, Vertex has worked in CF for 16 years so of course those programs moved faster and faster. But the new pipeline, good-luck.
Also,  The C suite pays themselves and gives themselves incredible raises and bonus while the employees who kill themselves and create great work get 2% raises.   I do not recommend this company; hence I left to find a place that respects Work/Life balance and doesn’t have such a greedy C suite.

pros: GREAT people to work with- especially Associate Director level and below.  Lots of young professionals, so high energy, great morale.  Work-life balance is amazing- working over time is not at all common and not expected.  Flexible work hours as long as line manager approves (they typically always do).  Unbelievable health, dental, pet care, tuition reimbursement, etc. and great pay.  Four weeks paid vacation to start, 5 years after being there 5 years.  Week between Christmas-New Years is closed.
cons: Re-orgs seem to happen frequently.  Pretty political place to work- as are almost all businesses.  Promotions seem very difficult and rare.  Not much of a career path for junior employees (up to manager level).  Dependent on department, many of the director level and above employees are ok, not great, and not loved by all who work under them.

review_title: Colleagues are leaving to escape mistreatment
pros: The benefits, assuming you can get permission to take a vacation. Vertex had a history of employees staying for a long time, but many of these folks have been laid off. Historically, people were promoted based on their contribution, the work they were actually doing, so job growth was rewarded. But that went away due to belt tightening. Unfortunately, Vertex's Pros are mostly a thing of the past.
cons: Horrible senior management that does not live by the Vertex corporate values, favoritism leading to promotions of people lacking the qualifications to do the job well, ongoing layoffs. Employees who are willing to stick it out are treated badly.

pros: Great salary and benefits.  Nice, modern location.  If you like playing politics and are introverted and quiet with hierarchical mindset and you manage get in with the right clique it may be great for you.   For most part there are really good, hard working people here.
cons: This department is a revolving door.   There is very limited science/medicine and no patient advocacy in this department but plenty of posturing and politics.  Company (and department) is run from top down.  There may be conflicting messages on what to do and how to do it which adds to the confusion because questioning authority in any capacity is discouraged.

pros: Really great science in challenging disease areas. Colleagues are highly trained and work hard under considerable time pressure. Growing company which can be an energising environment.
cons: Deadlines for delivering work are usually unrealistic. Very fearful culture, with senior management  pressing for results urgently, whether or not this is required. Values include "We wins", although the fear that project Leaders have that they will be berated by senior managers makes it a very uncollaborative environment.

review_title: Good Potential; but, Highly Smoke and Mirrors
pros: Vertex is progressive with it's medicines for the CF population - several new drugs have been approved and launched in short amount of time to help better and further the lives of those living with CF.  Science is at forefront.  Benefits and perks for an employee are great and highly competitive _ ample vacation and holiday time, stocks and bonuses, many discounted programs, commuter benefits and excellent health insurance.  If your a social extrovert, perfect place for you.  Sponsored happy hours every Friday and many other "social events".  Not so great if you're an introvert who goes to work, to work...
cons: Lack of diversity.  Lack of opportunities for supporting roles such as administrative or coordinator levels.  Environment is that of a highly 'favoritized' and political one.  Also, if you're not super social or are quiet, you're often outed as odd or not a "team player", even if you work hard and have high performance.  In my experience, there is a very high school - esque, not inclusive environment.  For me personally, there is a clear presence of a "mean-girl" mentality and subtle bullying in the form of gossip, hostile environment, sabotage and rumors.

pros:
-Benefits
-Pay
-Location
-Some people are smart and fun to be around
cons:
-Work/life balance STILL non-existent
-Required to multitask to ineffiency and burn out
-The churn of logistics disables the science
-Constant chaos, constant sprint, very disorganized

review_title: Great Potential, Managers need to support subordinates better!!
pros: Awesome work, great pay, potential for amazing opportunities, some of the most experienced and smart people..
cons:
People here often become tunnel visioned because the strenuous deadline, need more flexibility for actually working efficiently..
Politics is one of the worst things here, can make working here toxic(needs to stop, really!!)

review_title: Fantastic first job which grew stale due to to their direction of research
job_title: Research Scientist I in San Diego, CA
pros: Back in 2006 when I first joined the site in San Diego, Vertex was a special place. Scientists were excited about their work and one could sense the enthusiasm at project team meetings. Personally, I had a great experience my first 6 years there. The work-life balance is great, but it does depend on your group dynamics. And from what I've observed, the benefits are right up there at par with the best companies.
cons: Vertex has experienced an immense growth phase due to the success of 2 marketed drugs. As a result, the bureaucracy has increased to a ridiculous amount.  The values of the company have had to shift due to being a publicly traded company. There is nothing really exciting behind the CF drugs, so if they don't continue to work in the clinic, I smell trouble for the company.

pros: The culture is incredibly cross-functional, which is made enjoyable by having some of the most talented, hardworking, kind employees in the industry. The projects move at a very fast pace, but hearing regularly from patient speakers/visitors makes it easy to stay motivated and connected to the mission of helping those with serious diseases. The benefits are awesome (ample vacation time,  flexible hours, great cafeteria/beer hour +more), and there are a lot of fun internal events that help connect employees on a personal level as well as connect them to the business and values.
cons: The pace can be overwhelming, but the team atmosphere and promising science/strategy make each milestone that much more rewarding.

pros: Very good to employees!  They treat the temp employees just the same as the regular ones!  Great cafeteria with a spectacular view of Boston on sunny days!  Benefits are really good!  Everyone seems super helpful -- if you ask someone a question and they don't know the answer, they will find it for you or give you clear directions on where you can find it.
cons: Probably just that there is really no one-on-one training for your position.  It is a "learn as you go" position which in some ways is good, because it makes you really pay attention, but in other ways it can be bad because instead of completing a task someone asks you to do right away, you have to find out first how to do it and/or where to find the instructions on how to do it!

review_title: Want a life? Don't work here
pros: Benefits, PTO, compensation, location, facilities
cons:
- Some parts of the company work all the time - including Thanksgiving and Christmas. If you're not working nights and weekends, you're "not committed."
- Outdated model of needing to see "butts in the chair" despite the craziness this causes employees (who are working around the clock)
- Lack of leadership in some functions
- Micromanagement from all levels of leadership, yet senior managers are overwhelmed and can't make decisions
- Favoritism

pros: Benefits are amazing in general.  Start with 4wks of vacation plus company shut down between Christmas and New Years.  Very intelligent and hard working employees.  Disease area is very rewarding.  Great experience for people starting out their careers.
cons: Sr. Management tends to micro manage and constantly accelerate timelines beyond reason.  Work/life balance and mode of operation is not sustainable. You often work nights, weekends, and during vacation.  Career growth is limited.  Vision seems to be very short term and focused on short term gains. A lot of indecision or changing of decisions.

pros:
The stock price is poised to go through the roof.
Working on the edge of the financial district in the Innovation District is way cool.
cons:
The CEO and the rest of the C team are reviled for their exorbitant salaries.
The price of Vertex's drugs is controversial.
The Silver Line is so crowded, it's faster to walk to South Station.
The politics are tough; if you get on the wrong side of someone powerful, there's no future for you.
There's a solid chance that Vertex will get bought, in which case jobs will be lost.

review_title: Very good, but could be great.
pros:
Strong benefits
Competitive Salary and annual bonus
Generous vacation time
Various stock plans
401k match
Beautiful location
New, modern buildings
Social hours/regular events
Emphasis on patients
cons:
Depending on department:
Politics/Favoritism
Long hours/working from home/late at night/weekends.
Tight timelines
Regular "panic" mode
Lack of professional development/growth
Frequent re-organizations
Talent/backgrounds are often poorly utilized
Growing pains (historical R&D into Commercial)
Unfocused pipeline 

Not all people/departments will experience some of this, but several do.

pros:
Great pipeline
Hard working and smart employees
Creative approach to projects
Most individuals are very collaborative
cons: Working at Vertex for just over a year I experienced a lot of wonderful, smart and collaborative colleagues. However, I noticed there is a real problem with knowledge silos. There is also a lot of posturing among mid-management. It was disillusioning to me that individuals felt compelled to "one up" each other at meetings. In addition, I found that some individuals were very intractable and were inflexible about considering different ideas/approaches.

pros: Super bright scientists, top notch research, excellent benefits, and an unbeatable vacation policy (4 weeks starting PLUS a week off for the holidays). Most people are pleasant to work with, although with a company the size of Vertex, there are all different types of personality types. The new offices in Boston are gorgeous and the ocean views can't be beat. The surrounding neighborhood is up and coming and can only become better as more businesses move in to the area.
cons: The company has had to go through the growing pains of becoming a smaller, "wild west" company to becoming a true corporation. Many management changes and reorganizations have changed the culture a bit and have added a level of uncertainty to the atmosphere.

review_title: Company lost its way over the years
pros: Excellent pay and benefits. Great location (Boston). Definite passion for the science and work that the company does.
cons: The company used to have a focus on values and mission. Over the past few years, it really lost sight of these things. Leaders and leadership style seem to promote an atmosphere of everyone out for themselves / watch your back, rather than one of teamwork.

pros: Had some great years here until the new crew took over.
cons: Currently it is a rudderless ship full of manipulative self promoting snakes. If you are a white male BEWARE. Their diversity model does not include you. In fact, the more they hold down, the more "diverse" they appear.  Best move I made was leaving.

pros: I really enjoyed being an intern at Vertex, I was in an R&D role at the company. My manager was very excited about having an intern and had a great project for me. I was able to have a say in what I was doing and get direction and help at the same time. I felt like I was treated as a team member in the group and not below others. Great location.
cons: It was difficult to meet other interns outside of my department. There weren't really events for us to get to know each other until the end of the summer. Also, I am an undergraduate but the department I was working in doesn't hire many people directly from undergrad, they prefer them to have graduate degrees of some sort.

pros: Smart people and great work/life balance culture and a generous vacation time policy. Friday beer socials are great for hanging out with colleagues. I have a lot of independence and I'm not micromanaged. Can be fulfilling working on treating rare and challenging diseases.
cons: If you don't work in Boston or close to it, commuting to the waterfront can be a real pain (though it's nice once you're there). Salaries are OK but not great, although it can be made up for if you're there long enough to vest your stock awards (and the stock price doesn't fall). There can be the usual BS office politics.

pros:
The basic research area produces some really exciting science
The pipeline of products is rich and has great potential
There are plenty of excellent colleagues
The perks are good
Vertex makes life-changing therapies for patients
cons:
The company is very isolated from many current standard industry practices 
Communication is poor within teams and departments; employees have trouble understanding how to meet company needs
There is little respect for experience and knowledge; many very basic mistakes occur as a result
Lack of direction and focus; a company mission is very hard to identify
People are treated as though they are disposable
There is a chaotic work environment with much sudden quitting and firing of senior people which makes others understandably nervous

job_title: Clinical Trials Associate in Cambridge, MA
pros: Nice vacation and compensation. Great coworkers
cons: Will contradict their words and lay you off on maternity leave. Has untrained managers. Various positions are allowed to make untrue statements, provide zero proof and then not communicate the issues to  the accused. Cowardism is condoned and perpetuated. There is a large amount of preference in order to advance. No good growth and development.

review_title: It's hard to work with upper management and they over work the employees so people are stressed and on edge a lot.
job_title: Lab Tech in San Diego, CA
pros: The benefits are great and what keeps people working there for a long time. The company also has a great goal on improving lives for people with the diseases they work on.
cons: It is hard to work with the upper management. The work load given is way too much and long hours are a must to stay I top of the work load. Hard to have any life outside of work.

pros: Great benefits.  4 weeks vacation to start.  Great Fan Pier location.  Flexible work scheduled due to rough commute.  Beer hour on Thursdays!
cons: Sr. Management Team is clueless about the reality of day to day activities.  As a result, they make impractical and superficial decisions about staffing.  The "employment at will" makes me very nervous about security and fosters an environment of distrust and unnecessary competition which results in employment being a popularity vote instead of being about production and work quality.

pros: There are a lot of great people working at Vertex- bright, committed, energetic, and fun. The benefit package is excellent, especially the paid time off. They encourage community involvement in many regards.
cons:
The environment is very political - even office space is handed out by how much the VP of Operations likes your boss.  And if you even pretend to have a life outside the company, you will not get ahead.  Staff development is an afterthought here, and many managers completely lack this as a core competency and rely on HR to have the tough conversations for them. 

There are also a lot of folks there who seem to serve no other purpose than to create bureaucracy. The organization is extremely top heavy, and VP titles are handed out like candy on Halloween, creating a level of management that are leaders in title, but not in capability or responsibility. Some people's jobs are reduced to a fraction of their prior responsibility due to lack of capability, and yet they retain their title. The organization works in silos with one hand actively ignoring what the other is doing, leading to re-work and confusion, as well as overlapping roles that lack proper definition and appropriate communication.

As someone else posted here: though new ideas are encouraged, be careful who you voice them to. If you happen to get on the CSO's bad side - watch out. It only takes one wrong move, or the hearsay of one person, to get you blacklisted.

review_title: Fast-paced, challenging and innovative place to work with great employees
pros: Everyone at Vertex is extremely passionate about their work and helping patients, and it shows. From scientists at the bench to employees in G&A functions, and everyone in between, teams are always coming together to solve problems and innovate across the company so that we can get medicines to patients as fast as possible. It's inspiring to work with so many smart, passionate people - especially at a place that truly cares about my career growth and provides excellent benefits.
cons: Timelines are tight and expectations are high, so the work can be demanding at times - but it's worth it.

pros: Amazing culture, focused on both the patients and the employees. Senior leadership understands how critical it is that their employees are not only happy and engaged, but also have the time and tools to create the best work/life balance for themselves. I joined virtually at the start of the pandemic and was amazed at how seamless the onboarding was. They had seemingly thought of everything that could go wrong and already had a plan in place. I have never been in an organization where I felt so at home so quickly. Every employee has been warm, helpful and really embraces the Vertex phenotype of leading by example, learning, teaching and developing, fostering exceptional collaboration, driving breakthrough results and promoting enterprise thinking. These are all values which are a large part of what makes Vertex such a special place to work. Of course their benefits are incredible, and with the success they've experienced, there are lots of opportunities for future growth. What stood out to me immediately is how frequently they promote from within, along with a strong commitment to D&I. When I interviewed at their beautiful Seaport headquarters, I swear i could feel the positive energy the minute I stepped off the elevator. The funny thing is, I also feel that energy whenever we have a zoom meeting. It's the PEOPLE, and I am so excited to get back to the office when it is deemed safe to do so, and meet everyone in person!
cons: Every company has pros and cons, but I personally have not yet found anything that I would consider a con.

pros: It is a great place to work with great pay and benefits. Vertex Boston is located on the water fount of South Boston and has great views a great selection of local places to eat and visit. The buildings were just opened at the beginning of 2014 so we are currently in brand new start of the art lab space.
cons: there are not many. One would be the commute. Driving into Boston during rush hour on 93 is the pits!

review_title: This place makes me cry and drink heavily
pros: The pay is great, and we get a 401k match and annual stock grants.  Nice parking and commuter benefits. 4 weeks of vacation, if you can take it.  Nice cafeteria. Friday beer hour. On site gym for employees.
cons:
Stressful environment.  There are people working 12 hour days and still can't get their work done.  People generally don't even make it a year before they burn out. You have vacation time, but people will work through their vacation and weekends.  

You can't trust anyone - I have had people talk about me but I don't know who it was. There is a consistent high school mentality that permeates everything you do.  You don't know who is friends with whom, so you can't speak freely. Ever. You are not allowed to have an opinion. 

There are no team building or social activities. There really is no "team" at all because you have to watch your back. They do have beer hour on Fridays but most people are still working at 4pm when the beer hour starts. 

Rampant favoritism of the "veterans" (i.e. everyone who was here for the Hep C days). The veterans are always right. You are always wrong. This goes back to number 2 - don't offer opinions. Don't point out serious problems. Don't make jokes. Don't even say good morning. At best, you will be ignored. At worst, what you say can and will be held against you. It's extra fun when you watch the "veterans" get the praise, awards and raises while you sit silently being happy that you got free coffee today.  

No respect.  My manager didn't care that my grandmother died, as long as I made it to work.  Even though I'm highly educated, people talk over me at meetings and interrupt me when I speak.  I was even told that I should be a "silent observer" so now I don't talk at all.   

No diversity. I was shocked at how there were no people of color or women in the C suite. They will tell you it's one of the values, but it isn't true. 

Every mistake you have ever made will be held against you.  Did you  make a typo on that document 6 months ago?  You will see it again in your performance review.  All those 9,352 things you did right?  Too bad. That was your job and you should have done those things right.

pros: Vacation time, benefits, compensation in a nutshell. A lot of people are very smart and motivated. The building is great.
cons: The politics are  dirty, and the work life balance creates a lot of 'unnecessary' stress. The favorites will keep getting promoted like clockwork, so if you care about a career, it's either kiss up or kiss goodbye.

pros: The Benefits are really good
cons:
Where to start.... 
way too many VP’s, Senior Directors, Associate Directors and upper management. 
Those who work hard are not rewarded. 
When complaints are made to direct managers regarding issues, there are policies in place yet they get ignored and when complaints are made to HR, they are down played.
The culture went down hill after the move to Fan Pier. Not a “fun” place to work. 
Too many people that feel they are entitled and feel they don’t need to work as hard as some of their peers. 
Career development is just for the special few.

pros: The benefits are amazing, 4 weeks of vacation, 1 week sick time, and 2 floating holidays to start. pros: Benefits are great, flexible working etc etc, but at a cost

cons: As a growing company, it is difficult to avoid bureaucracy.  There is room for improvement and ways to make the system more efficient.

review_title: Hard work some compensation for this.

review_title: An abysmal company that reads a reset...
pros:
I've worked in two separate R&D groups while at Vertex. There are few "pros" to working for this company. The benefits are decent. The medical coverage is slightly above industry average, legal insurance is offered and there are several other types of insurance which is offered (i.e. pet). 
A second "pro" is if you take the MBTA, your commute into south Boston is tolerable. If you drive, good luck. The rate of commercial/residential development in south Boston is astounding, which is slowly making the commute via personal transportation impossible. The new location is pretty. 
Third, some of your immediate co-workers are great although the environment is very cliquey. 
Some of the benefits, the commute/company location and some co-workers is really it.
cons:
There is absolutely no career development. None. Your day to day work is extremely niched. Once you have been at the company for a short bit, you simply become a technician that follows poorly written protocols and SOPs. Trying to break out of this niched work to professionally grow is tiresome and you will eventually be labeled as problematic. Your talents, professional interests and previous work experience really don't mean anything. 

Inept middle and upper management with no sense of professionalism. It is encouraged to "listen hard and debate hard". However, if you "debate hard" and work to come to a resolution that isn't part of your management's vision, you are talked down to and marginalized out of the work. The company's core values are rarely and selectively followed. Very little accountability and consistency amongst the management with concern to following the corporate values and the treatment of staff. The focus and direction of the workflows change on a weekly basis due to poor decision making and lack of accountability. This inept (current and former) management has lead to compliance issues within the company. 

Profitability and company sustainability. The company has been around for over a quarter century and profits are still not in the black. The product "pipeline" is referred to internally as more of a "trickling garden hose". It's great that CF is the company's primary focus, but there are no other therapeutic areas that are being focused on. The focus with projects in other (potential) therapeutic areas is erratic, poorly organized and extremely political. This leads to very high levels of stress, irrelevantly long days and staff burn out.

Do your due diligence before applying here. There is an exodus with the staff due to the abysmal environment here. Firings, some seemingly random, are very common. Smart, independent and creative thinkers will eventually be viewed as non-compliant and will be dealt with accordingly. Be wary of the brief 5 star company reviews with this company as well. There is definitely some internal/external "reputation management" going on. It's a very small world in pharma here in Boston. Dig and ask around before applying for any R&D based position at Vertex. HR, the recruiters and the interviewers will make Vertex sound like utopia while it's just the opposite.

review_title: Vertex - Great pay/benefits, decent science, awful management.
job_title: Senior Scientist II in Boston, MA
pros: Compensation is good. My benefits/ salary/ retirement were good as a junior scientist (<5 years experience) with a PhD. The work spaces were very nice in downtown Boston. The science was in general good (orkambi, kalydeco) to not-so-good (incivek).
cons: Many decisions were based on non-scientific considerations; I once presented data to a VP in my area and he effectively ignored the science and told my boss and I that's not how he was going to present it to the (then) CSO, which I believe was due to impending bonuses based off of internal metrics. The integrity of management was suspect to say the least, as I witnessed scary inquiries by the US SEC (google "Vertex COO and SEC" if you don't believe it) and massive issues in the DMPK group regarding data integrity which resulted in effectively dissolving the internal group in favor of outsourcing all the work. Middle-management was constantly competing with other groups in the company for clout/ political turf, which made working at the team level very difficult as folks were often getting thrown under the bus. Vertex was/ is in the habit of making announcements through the press, which is certainly a double-edged sword and in my mind bad practice. Additionally, HR is nothing more than a hire/ fire department; many times I brought up inconsistencies with management and in one instance how an internal survey conducted indicated there needed more management engagement with "lower" employees, but in discussion with HR there wasn't going to be any transparency regarding the metrics of the survey because ultimately management didn't want to accept long-term culpability. Lastly employee turnover is incredibly high, read between the lines.
